mn7:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn7:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn7:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

mn7:2.1.eng: “Suppose, mendicants, there was a cloth that was dirty and soiled.

mn7:2.2.pli: tamenaṃ rajako yasmiṃ yasmiṃ raṅgajāte upasaṃhareyya—yadi nīlakāya yadi pītakāya yadi lohitakāya yadi mañjiṭṭhakāya durattavaṇṇamevassa aparisuddhavaṇṇamevassa.
mn7:2.2.eng: No matter what dye the dyer applied—whether blue or yellow or red or magenta—it would look poorly dyed and impure in color.

mn7:2.4.eng: Because of the impurity of the cloth.

mn7:2.5.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, citte saṅkiliṭṭhe, duggati pāṭikaṅkhā.
mn7:2.5.eng: In the same way, when the mind is corrupt, a bad destiny is to be expected.
mn7:2.5.comm: A “bad destiny” (duggati) is any realm below the human, namely the animal, ghost, and hell realms.

mn7:2.6.eng: Suppose there was a cloth that was pure and clean.

mn7:2.7.pli: tamenaṃ rajako yasmiṃ yasmiṃ raṅgajāte upasaṃhareyya—yadi nīlakāya yadi pītakāya yadi lohitakāya yadi mañjiṭṭhakāya—surattavaṇṇamevassa parisuddhavaṇṇamevassa.
mn7:2.7.eng: No matter what dye the dyer applied—whether blue or yellow or red or magenta—it would look well dyed and pure in color.

mn7:2.9.eng: Because of the purity of the cloth.

mn7:2.10.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, citte asaṅkiliṭṭhe, sugati pāṭikaṅkhā.
mn7:2.10.eng: In the same way, when the mind isn’t corrupt, a good destiny is to be expected.

mn7:3.1.eng: And what are the corruptions of the mind?
mn7:3.1.comm: Here the text shifts from saṅkiliṭṭha (“corrupt”) to upakkilesa (“corruption”). These are general terms for unskillful qualities of mind and the change in prefix has no particular significence.

mn7:3.2.pli: Abhijjhāvisamalobho cittassa upakkileso, byāpādo cittassa upakkileso, kodho cittassa upakkileso, upanāho cittassa upakkileso, makkho cittassa upakkileso, paḷāso cittassa upakkileso, issā cittassa upakkileso, macchariyaṃ cittassa upakkileso, māyā cittassa upakkileso, sāṭheyyaṃ cittassa upakkileso, thambho cittassa upakkileso, sārambho cittassa upakkileso, māno cittassa upakkileso, atimāno cittassa upakkileso, mado cittassa upakkileso, pamādo cittassa upakkileso.
mn7:3.2.eng: Covetousness and immoral greed, ill will, anger, acrimony, disdain, contempt, jealousy, stinginess, deceit, deviousness, obstinacy, aggression, conceit, arrogance, vanity, and negligence are corruptions of the mind.

mn7:4.1.pli: Sa kho so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘abhijjhāvisamalobho cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā abhijjhāvisamalobhaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahati;
mn7:4.1.eng: A mendicant who understands that covetousness and immoral greed are corruptions of the mind gives them up.

mn7:4.2.eng: A mendicant who understands that ill will …

mn7:4.3.pli: iti viditvā byāpādaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahati;

mn7:4.5.pli: iti viditvā kodhaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahati;

mn7:4.7.pli: iti viditvā upanāhaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahati;

mn7:4.9.pli: iti viditvā makkhaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahati;

mn7:4.11.pli: iti viditvā paḷāsaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahati;

mn7:4.13.pli: iti viditvā issaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahati;

mn7:4.15.pli: iti viditvā macchariyaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahati;

mn7:4.17.pli: iti viditvā māyaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahati;

mn7:4.19.pli: iti viditvā sāṭheyyaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahati;

mn7:4.21.pli: iti viditvā thambhaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahati;

mn7:4.23.pli: iti viditvā sārambhaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahati;

mn7:4.25.pli: iti viditvā mānaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahati;

mn7:4.27.pli: iti viditvā atimānaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahati;

mn7:4.29.pli: iti viditvā madaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahati;

mn7:4.30.eng: negligence is a corruption of the mind gives it up.

mn7:4.31.pli: iti viditvā pamādaṃ cittassa upakkilesaṃ pajahati.

mn7:5.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ‘abhijjhāvisamalobho cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā abhijjhāvisamalobho cittassa upakkileso pahīno hoti,
mn7:5.1.eng: When they have understood these corruptions of the mind

mn7:5.2.eng: for what they are, and have given them up,

mn7:5.3.pli: iti viditvā byāpādo cittassa upakkileso pahīno hoti;

mn7:5.5.pli: iti viditvā kodho cittassa upakkileso pahīno hoti;

mn7:5.7.pli: iti viditvā upanāho cittassa upakkileso pahīno hoti;

mn7:5.9.pli: iti viditvā makkho cittassa upakkileso pahīno hoti;

mn7:5.11.pli: iti viditvā paḷāso cittassa upakkileso pahīno hoti;

mn7:5.13.pli: iti viditvā issā cittassa upakkileso pahīno hoti;

mn7:5.15.pli: iti viditvā macchariyaṃ cittassa upakkileso pahīno hoti;

mn7:5.17.pli: iti viditvā māyā cittassa upakkileso pahīno hoti;

mn7:5.19.pli: iti viditvā sāṭheyyaṃ cittassa upakkileso pahīno hoti;

mn7:5.21.pli: iti viditvā thambho cittassa upakkileso pahīno hoti;

mn7:5.23.pli: iti viditvā sārambho cittassa upakkileso pahīno hoti;

mn7:5.25.pli: iti viditvā māno cittassa upakkileso pahīno hoti;

mn7:5.27.pli: iti viditvā atimāno cittassa upakkileso pahīno hoti;

mn7:5.29.pli: iti viditvā mado cittassa upakkileso pahīno hoti;

mn7:5.31.pli: iti viditvā pamādo cittassa upakkileso pahīno hoti.

mn7:5.32.eng: they have experiential confidence in the Buddha:
mn7:5.32.comm: “Experiential” is avecca, literally “having undergone”. “Experiential confidence” is the faith of a stream-enterer, who has seen for themselves.

mn7:5.33.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti;
mn7:5.33.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
mn7:5.33.comm: They have experiential confidence in the Buddha as a teacher because they have followed his path and realized the results that he speaks of.

mn7:6.1.eng: They have experiential confidence in the teaching:

mn7:6.2.pli: ‘svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī’ti;
mn7:6.2.eng: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.’
mn7:6.2.comm: A stream-enterer has direct experience of the four noble truths, so they have confirmed that the teaching is indeed realizable in this very life.

mn7:7.1.eng: They have experiential confidence in the Saṅgha:

mn7:7.2.pli: ‘suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, ujuppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, ñāyappaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, sāmīcippaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, yadidaṃ cattāri purisayugāni, aṭṭha purisapuggalā. Esa bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho āhuneyyo pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo, anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā’ti.
mn7:7.2.eng: ‘The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is practicing the way that’s good, direct, systematic, and proper. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individual persons. This is the Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples that is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.’
mn7:7.2.comm: The suttas distinguish between two senses of Saṅgha. The “mendicant Saṅgha” (bhikkhusaṅgha) is the conventional community of monks and nuns. The “Saṅgha of disciples” (sāvakasaṅgha) is classified as fourfold according to the stages of awakening: stream-entry, once-return, non-return, and perfection. Each of these stages is further subdivided into those of the path who are practicing for realization and those of the fruit who have realized. These are referred to as “noble disciples”, four of the path and four of the fruit, making eight individuals in total. Saṅgha is not used in the sense of “spiritual community”.

mn7:8.1.pli: Yathodhi kho panassa cattaṃ hoti vantaṃ muttaṃ pahīnaṃ paṭinissaṭṭhaṃ, so ‘buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgatomhī’ti labhati atthavedaṃ, labhati dhammavedaṃ, labhati dhammūpasaṃhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ.
mn7:8.1.eng: When a mendicant has discarded, eliminated, released, given up, and relinquished to this extent, thinking, ‘I have experiential confidence in the Buddha …

mn7:8.2.pli: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vedeti, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati;

mn7:10.1.pli: saṅghe aveccappasādena samannāgatomhī’ti labhati atthavedaṃ, labhati dhammavedaṃ, labhati dhammūpasaṃhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ;
mn7:10.1.eng: the Saṅgha,’ they find inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and find joy connected with the teaching.

mn7:10.2.pli: pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vedeti, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.

mn7:11.1.pli: ‘Yathodhi kho pana me cattaṃ vantaṃ muttaṃ pahīnaṃ paṭinissaṭṭhan’ti labhati atthavedaṃ, labhati dhammavedaṃ, labhati dhammūpasaṃhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ;
mn7:11.1.eng: Thinking: ‘I have discarded, eliminated, released, given up, and relinquished to this extent,’ they find inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and find joy connected with the teaching.

mn7:11.2.pli: pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vedeti, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
mn7:11.2.eng: When they’re joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss. And when they’re blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.
mn7:11.2.comm: Reflection on one’s progress brings joy and spurs further progress. This can be so powerful as to be a basis for samādhi.

mn7:12.1.pli: Sa kho so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃsīlo evaṃdhammo evaṃpañño sālīnañcepi piṇḍapātaṃ bhuñjati vicitakāḷakaṃ anekasūpaṃ anekabyañjanaṃ, nevassa taṃ hoti antarāyāya.
mn7:12.1.eng: When a mendicant of such ethics, such qualities, and such wisdom eats boiled fine rice with the dark grains picked out and served with many soups and sauces, that is no obstacle for them.
mn7:12.1.comm: An offering of delicious food is normally the most sensual temptation in a mendicant’s day. In the Chinese parallel at EA 13.5, this is mentioned only after arahantship.

mn7:12.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, vatthaṃ saṅkiliṭṭhaṃ malaggahitaṃ acchodakaṃ āgamma parisuddhaṃ hoti pariyodātaṃ, ukkāmukhaṃ vā panāgamma jātarūpaṃ parisuddhaṃ hoti pariyodātaṃ;
mn7:12.2.eng: Compare with cloth that is dirty and soiled; it can be made pure and clean by pure water. Or native gold, which can be made pure and bright by a forge.

mn7:12.3.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃsīlo evaṃdhammo evaṃpañño sālīnañcepi piṇḍapātaṃ bhuñjati vicitakāḷakaṃ anekasūpaṃ anekabyañjanaṃ, nevassa taṃ hoti antarāyāya.
mn7:12.3.eng: In the same way, when a mendicant of such ethics, such qualities, and such wisdom eats boiled fine rice with the dark grains picked out and served with many soups and sauces, that is no obstacle for them.

mn7:13.1.pli: So mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ, tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati;
mn7:13.1.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
mn7:13.1.comm: Here the Buddha introduces the so-called “divine meditations” (brahmavihāra) or “immeasurables” (appamañña). These are four wholesome emotional states that can be developed as a basis for samādhi. They were evidently pre-Buddhist, although they have not been traced as a group in pre-Buddhist texts. However, they are shared with later non-Buddhist texts such as Yogasūtra 1.33 and the Jain Tattvārthasūtra 7.11. | “Love” (mettā) is a universal positive regard and well-wishing free of personal desires or attachments.

mn7:14.1.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of compassion to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of compassion to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
mn7:14.1.comm: “Compassion” (karuṇā) is the quality of empathy with the suffering of another or oneself and the wish to remove it.

mn7:15.1.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of rejoicing to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
mn7:15.1.comm: “Rejoicing” (muditā) is joyful celebration in the success of others or oneself, free of jealousy or cynicism.

mn7:16.1.pli: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ, tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
mn7:16.1.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
mn7:16.1.comm: Equanimity (upekkhā) is literally “close watching”, not interfering but standing ready when needed. It is not indifference, which is why it emerges only at the end, after the positive emotions are developed.

mn7:17.1.pli: So ‘atthi idaṃ, atthi hīnaṃ, atthi paṇītaṃ, atthi imassa saññāgatassa uttari nissaraṇan’ti pajānāti.
mn7:17.1.eng: They understand: ‘There is this, there is what is worse than this, there is what is better than this, and there is an escape beyond the scope of perception.’
mn7:17.1.comm: This is a description of advanced insight by a stream-enterer. The meditator understands the current state of their experience, namely the mind developed through samādhi. They know that this is conditioned and hence liable to decline to a lower state “worse than this”. They know that there are still higher states of mind that can be developed. And they know that, while all states of meditation fall within the scope of perception, there is an ultimate escape, namely Nibbāna.

mn7:18.1.pli: Tassa evaṃ jānato evaṃ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati.
mn7:18.1.eng: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

mn7:18.2.eng: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

mn7:18.3.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
mn7:18.3.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’

mn7:18.5.eng: a mendicant who is bathed with the inner bathing.”
mn7:18.5.comm: “Bathed” is sināta, a rare variant spelling of nhata (Sanskrit snāta. Sināta also occurs at SN 7.9:15.3). | Later Brahmanical texts regarded external bathing as spiritually effective only when accompanied by inner bathing or purity of soul. The Mahābhārata says that “he who is bathed in the bath of self-disciple is clean inside and out” (13.111.9c, sa snāto yo damasnātaḥ sabāhyābhyantaraḥ śuciḥ), while the Liṅga-purāṇa (1.8.33) insists that one who has bathed externally “must also practice the inner bathing” (snānaṁ … ābhyantaraṁ caret).

mn7:19.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sundarikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavato avidūre nisinno hoti.
mn7:19.1.eng: Now at that time the brahmin Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā was sitting not far from the Buddha.
mn7:19.1.comm: It seems that the Buddha mentioned the inner bathing to provoke the brahmin. | Four of the six Chinese parallels to this passage situate it on the bank of a river.

mn7:19.2.pli: Atha kho sundarikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

mn7:19.3.pli: “gacchati pana bhavaṃ gotamo bāhukaṃ nadiṃ sināyitun”ti?
mn7:19.3.eng: “But does the worthy Gotama go to the river Bāhuka to bathe?”

mn7:19.4.eng: “Brahmin, why go to the river Bāhuka?

mn7:19.5.eng: What can the river Bāhuka do?”

mn7:19.6.pli: “Lokkhasammatā hi, bho gotama, bāhukā nadī bahujanassa, puññasammatā hi, bho gotama, bāhukā nadī bahujanassa, bāhukāya pana nadiyā bahujano pāpakammaṃ kataṃ pavāhetī”ti.
mn7:19.6.eng: “Many people deem that the river Bāhukā leads to a heavenly world and bestows merit. And many people rinse off their bad deeds in the river Bāhukā.”
mn7:19.6.comm: Lokkha, elsewhere unattested in Pali, is Sanskrit lokya, which occurs several times in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa in the sense “conducive to a (heavenly) world” (9.5.2.16, 10.5.2.12, 11.3.3.7). The root sense of loka is “light” and it was originally the bright sky with its devas (eg. Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa Mādyandina 11.2.3.1–6, Kāṇva 3.2.5.1), later being extended to include all worlds. The PTS reading mokkha is an unwarranted normalization, although it is supported by the parallel at MA 93, which has 度. Note that the expected form lokiya, although common in later Pali, occurs only in one early verse (Thag 2.18:2.4). | Bathing for purity from misdeeds as a pre-Buddhist Brahmanical custom is attested in Śukla Yajurveda 3.48. The bhikkhunī Puṇṇikā pointed out that if this were true then the fish, frogs, and turtles would go to heaven (Thig 12.1:6.1); her argument was echoed by the Jains (Sūyagaḍa 1.7.14–16) and later Brahmins (Liṅga-purāṇa 1.8.33–4).

mn7:20.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sundarikabhāradvājaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
mn7:20.1.eng: Then the Buddha addressed Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā in verse:

mn7:20.2.comm: The Bāhukā (variant Bahukā) is mentioned only here. It may be the Bāhudā found in various Sanskrit texts (Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.19.18), both words having the sense “granter of abundance”. | Adhikakkā (variant Avikakkā) is mentioned only here. The commentary says it was a ford (tittha).

mn7:20.3.eng: at Gayā and the Sundarikā too,
mn7:20.3.comm: Gayā is a ford on the Phalgu River by the town of Gayā, which is still a popular site for sacred bathing. Legend has it that it was named after the great titan of that name who offered his own body in sacrifice (Vāyu Purāṇa vol. ii, 43.5, Tagare translation). | Sundarikā was a river in Kosala used for Brahmanical rituals (SN 7.9, Snp 3.4). Bathing in the ford there was said to bring beauty (Mahābhārata 3.82.51).

mn7:20.4.comm: Pali sarassatī is better known in the Sanskrit form sarasvatī, the most prominent river of the Vedas, who “like a snorting boar, broke the back of the mountains with her mighty waves” (Rig Veda 6.61.2). Change stole her waters and today she is lost. Researchers have identified her with the now-residual Ghaggar-Hakra system in north-west India and Pakistan or the Helmand River in Afghanistan. | Payāga (modern Prayagraj, formerly Allahabad) is the sacred ford at the confluence of the Ganges and the Yamunā beside Kosambī (see Bu Pj 1:4.18). The Mahābhārata calls it the “vulva of the world” (3.83.71), the most meritorious of all fords, where bathing can wash away a hundred crimes (3.83.82).

mn7:20.5.comm: The Bāhumatī River is elsewhere only known by a passing mention in Sanskrit reference works. As an epithet of Indra it means “strong of arm”.

mn7:20.6.eng: a fool can constantly plunge into them

mn7:20.7.eng: but it won’t purify their dark deeds.

mn7:20.9.eng: What the Payāga or the Bāhukā?

mn7:20.10.eng: They can’t cleanse a cruel person, a sinner

mn7:20.12.eng: For the pure in heart it’s always

mn7:20.13.eng: the spring festival or the sabbath.
mn7:20.13.comm: “Spring festival” is phaggu, said to be held at Gayā (Thag 5.7:1.4, Thag 4.6:1.2), although Sanskrit sources take it as the name of a river at Gayā.

mn7:20.14.eng: For the pure in heart and clean of deed,

mn7:20.15.eng: their vows will always be fulfilled.

mn7:20.16.eng: It’s here alone that you should bathe, brahmin,

mn7:20.17.eng: making yourself a sanctuary for all creatures.
mn7:20.17.comm: A khema (“sanctuary”) is a place of safety for wild creatures, a meaning featured in several Jātaka stories (eg. Ja 482).

mn7:20.18.eng: And if you speak no lies,
mn7:20.18.comm: The straightforward ethical teachings here contrast with the more demanding teachings for the mendicants in the previous prose. Such teachings presage the universal values of dharma promoted by King Asoka in his edicts.

mn7:20.21.eng: and you’re faithful and not stingy:

mn7:20.22.eng: what’s the point of going to Gayā?
mn7:20.22.comm: A counterpoint to Vāyu Purāṇa vol. ii, 43.15, where all the means of attaining liberation are made redundant by making an offering at Gayā: “If the son goes to Gayā, of what avail is the knowledge of Brahman? What is the necessity of dying in a cowshed? And what is the need for a residence at Kurukṣetra?”

mn7:20.23.eng: For any well may be your Gayā!”

mn7:21.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, sundarikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn7:21.1.eng: When he had spoken, the brahmin Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā said to the Buddha,

mn7:21.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya—cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantīti; evamevaṃ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
mn7:21.3.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.

mn7:21.4.pli: Esāhaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
mn7:21.4.eng: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

mn7:21.5.pli: Labheyyāhaṃ bhoto gotamassa santike pabbajjaṃ, labheyyaṃ upasampadan”ti.
mn7:21.5.eng: May I receive the going forth, the ordination in the worthy Gotama’s presence?”

mn7:22.1.pli: Alattha kho sundarikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, alattha upasampadaṃ.
mn7:22.1.eng: And the brahmin Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.

mn7:22.2.pli: Acirūpasampanno kho panāyasmā bhāradvājo eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
mn7:22.2.eng: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Bhāradvāja, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

mn7:22.3.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
mn7:22.3.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

mn7:22.4.pli: Aññataro kho panāyasmā bhāradvājo arahataṃ ahosīti.
mn7:22.4.eng: And Venerable Bhāradvāja became one of the perfected.
